dialogue.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?

Hey, thanks for being here. I’ve just been feeling really overwhelmed with school and I can't seem to find the motivation to get my work done. It's like I'm stuck in a cycle and I don't know how to break it.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their concerns and feelings comprehensively, including their struggle with motivation and academic pressure. They've provided detailed context about their situation and emotions. Empathy and rapport have been established, and the client has expressed a desire for advice, indicating a mutually agreed goal to explore solutions.

dialogue.statement: It sounds like you're really struggling with feeling overwhelmed and stuck. What would life look like for you if you could find that motivation and break this cycle?

client(guiding): I guess if I could find that motivation, I'd feel more in control of my days. I'd be on top of my assignments and able to actually enjoy college life without the constant stress hanging over me.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear desire for change, imagining life with more motivation and less stress. They've shown understanding of the benefits but haven't expressed specific steps or confidence yet. There's a need to further explore and clarify their confidence and specific goals, as well as decrease ambivalence.

dialogue.statement: Imagining feeling more in control and enjoying college life without stress sounds really appealing. What would being on top of your assignments mean for your sense of accomplishment and enjoyment in your daily life?

client(reflecting): I think being on top of my assignments would definitely make me feel more accomplished and less anxious. It would probably give me more confidence and allow me to focus on things I enjoy outside of school too.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed specific goals around feeling in control and enjoying college life, describing the benefits of being on top of assignments. Change Talk is present, but no specific action steps or high confidence levels are evident yet, and ambivalence remains. More exploration of motivation and confidence building is needed.

dialogue.statement: Feeling more accomplished and less anxious sounds like it could really enhance your college experience. What small steps do you think might help you start moving toward that sense of confidence and enjoyment?

client(reflecting): I think maybe setting up a more structured daily routine could be a good start. Like, making sure I get up at the same time every day and setting specific times for studying and breaks might help me feel more organized and less overwhelmed.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively evoked the discrepancy between current behavior and desired goals, explored life with change, and the client has expressed specific change steps like setting up a structured routine. Change Talk is present, and the client seems ready to start planning specific actions. Ambivalence is reduced as the client identifies potential steps, suggesting readiness to move.

dialogue.statement: Creating a structured routine sounds like a promising step towards feeling more organized and less overwhelmed. Based on what you've shared, some options might include setting regular wake-up times, designating specific study periods, or incorporating breaks to recharge. What do you think would work best for you in creating this routine?

client(choosing): I think starting with regular wake-up times would make a big difference. Once I get that down, I can try setting specific study periods and remember to take breaks so I don't burn out. It's probably all about building some consistency first.

statement.reasoning: The client has outlined a specific action plan to establish a routine with regular wake-up times as a starting point. Barriers, such as burnout, have been considered with the inclusion of breaks. The client is showing readiness through commitment to taking steps, and confidence is reflected in the plan to build consistency. Thus, goals for the Choosing phase are met.

dialogue.statement:
That sounds like a really solid plan. Establishing regular wake-up times can be a great foundation for building consistency and gaining that sense of control you’re looking for. You’re setting yourself up for success by taking it one step at a time. It’s impressive how you’re focusing on manageable steps to create a routine that supports your well-being.

As you move forward, remember to be gentle with yourself. It's perfectly okay to make adjustments as you figure out what works best for you. If you ever feel stuck or need a bit of encouragement, I'm here to support you. Your dedication to improving your situation is truly commendable.

For now, maybe focus on getting into the habit of those regular wake-up times this week. Then, we can touch base next time and see how it’s going, and perhaps even brainstorm further steps if you’re ready. You've got this!
Thanks, I appreciate the support and encouragement. I'll focus on starting with the wake-up times this week and let you know how it goes.

statement.reasoning: The client and therapist have summarized goals and steps, including setting a routine to manage anxiety and work. A next-step plan is discussed, focusing on consistent wake-up times. Closure is achieved, so it is appropriate to end the session.

concern:
title: i’ve been skipping classes and putting little to no effort into assignments and idk how to get outa the hole im in
i need advice 

i’m a college freshman in my second semester and i haven’t had any motivation to get any of my work done for my college courses. in highschool i was on top of my stuff all the time and looking back i don’t know how i managed to work part time and take 7 classes. I’m only taking 4 classes (16 credits) and i feel so unmotivated and overwhelmed.  my earliest class is at 11am and i can’t get myself up out of bed to go every morning. i don’t know what to do or how to get out of the funk i’m in. 

One of my college professors emailed me saying that I need to be more active and participate in class because my grade is low. The course material have the time is completely difficult for me to understand and I always attend office hours to try and get more help but I just can’t seem to graph the concept sometimes. it just makes me feel guilty and then when I do attend class I feel like I’m the only person that’s not understanding what’s being taught.  I had to drop one my labs the semester because I didn’t have the time and I stopped putting in the effort to try and get all of the work done. I was putting in about three hours of prep work for a class that I only had once a week, which I think is absolutely ridiculous. The lecture for that class takes about nine hours of work outside of the lectures. 

at this point I just have no idea what to do and how to get out of this hole that I’m in


TLDR , I’ve been procrastinating course work and have had little motivation when it comes to school and I don’t know what to do.
